content: The "James Boulet National Language Act of 2014" establishes English as the official language of the government. The "James Boulet National Language Act of 2014" establishes English as the official language of the United States government for all official activities and materials. It also emphasizes the preservation and enhancement of English as the official language, with limited exceptions specified by law. The "James Boulet National Language Act of 2014" establishes English as the official language of the United States government for all official activities and materials. Exceptions include using other languages for religious purposes, international communication training, and language learning programs in schools. Non-English forms issued by the Federal Government are only valid in English for legal purposes. The chapter allows the US Government to provide interpreters for individuals over 62 years old. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF BILINGUAL VOTING REQUIREMENTS. The curr_chunk discusses the repeal of bilingual election requirements under Section 203 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and the amendment of Section 4 by striking subsection (f). Conforming amendments are made to references to Section 203 and Section 4 within the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The Reauthorization and Amendments Act of 2006 is amended by removing certain language related to guarantees and declaratory judgments in various sections. The Reauthorization and Amendments Act of 2006 is amended to address denials or abridgments of the right to vote in violation of guarantees. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require all citizenship ceremonies to be conducted in English. This Act and its amendments do not preempt any state laws.
